documents.content:
# Reporting Water Quality Problems

## Where to Report

### Drinking Water Concerns
- Contact your water utility first
- DDW complaint hotline: (916) 449-5600
- [Submit a complaint online](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/about_us/contact_us/) through the SWRCB contact portal

### Surface Water/Pollution
- Regional Water Board
- [CalEPA Environmental Complaint System](https://calepa.ca.gov/enforcement/complaints/)
- Local environmental health

### Emergency Spills
- 911 for immediate danger
- OES spill hotline: (800) 852-7550
- National Response Center: (800) 424-8802

## What Information to Provide

### For Drinking Water
- Your water system name
- Nature of problem
- When noticed
- Who affected
- Your contact information

### For Pollution/Spills
- Location (address or coordinates)
- What you observed
- When you observed it
- Photos if safe to take
- Responsible party if known

## What Happens After Report

### Investigation
- Agency reviews complaint
- May contact you for details
- Inspect or investigate
- Take samples if needed

### Response
- Enforcement if violation found
- Corrective action required
- Follow-up with complainant

## Anonymous Reporting
- Can report anonymously
- Limits follow-up ability
- Still investigated

## Tracking Your Complaint
- Request case number
- Follow up with agency
- Public records request if needed

## Take Action

1. **Report drinking water issues** -- Contact your utility first, then file a complaint through the [SWRCB Contact Portal](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/about_us/contact_us/) or call DDW at (916) 449-5600.
2. **Report environmental pollution** -- Submit a complaint through the [CalEPA Environmental Complaint System](https://calepa.ca.gov/enforcement/complaints/) for water pollution, illegal discharge, or contamination.
3. **Find your local DDW office** -- Visit the [DDW District Offices](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/districts/) directory to find the drinking water district office that oversees your area.
4. **Report emergencies immediately** -- For spills or immediate health threats, call 911 or the OES spill hotline at (800) 852-7550.

# Understanding Your Water Bill

## Bill Components

### Fixed Charges
- Service charge (meter cost)
- Readiness to serve
- Capital improvement charge
- Not based on usage

### Variable Charges
- Based on water used
- Measured in CCF, HCF, or gallons
- May have tiered rates

### Other Charges
- Sewer (often on water bill)
- Stormwater fee
- Low-income surcharge
- Bond payments

## Reading Your Meter

### Meter Location
- Usually near curb
- In meter box with lid
- May require tool to open

### Understanding Reading
- Numbers show water used
- CCF = 100 cubic feet = 748 gallons
- Compare to previous reading

## High Bill Investigation

### Check for Leaks
- Toilet leak test (dye in tank)
- Dripping faucets
- Irrigation leaks
- Water heater leaks

### Meter Check
- Turn off all water
- Check if meter still moving
- Movement indicates leak

### Contact Utility
- Request meter test
- Discuss billing adjustment
- Payment plan if needed

## Assistance Programs

### Low-Income Assistance
- [California Low-Income Water Rate Assistance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/assistance/) programs
- Utility programs
- Local assistance

### Payment Plans
- Most utilities offer payment plans
- Prevents shutoff
- Contact before past due

For regulated utilities, the [CPUC Water Utility Rates](https://www.cpuc.ca.gov/industries-and-topics/water) page explains rate-setting and consumer rights. Visit [DWR Water Use Efficiency](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency) for conservation tips that can lower your bill.

## Take Action

1. **Check your rate structure** -- Visit the [CPUC Water Utility Rates](https://www.cpuc.ca.gov/industries-and-topics/water) page to understand how water rates are set for regulated utilities and your rights as a consumer.
2. **Apply for assistance** -- Visit the [California Low-Income Water Rate Assistance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/assistance/) page to see if you qualify for rate reductions or bill assistance.
3. **Reduce your bill** -- Explore [DWR Water Use Efficiency](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency) resources for indoor and outdoor conservation tips to lower water usage.
4. **Contact your utility** -- Call the customer service number on your water bill to request a meter test, discuss billing adjustments, or set up a payment plan.

# Water Shutoff Protections in California

## Residential Protections

### Before Shutoff Required
- Written notice (at least 7 days)
- Opportunity to pay
- Payment plan option
- Contact information provided

### When Shutoff Prohibited
- During extreme heat events
- If creates health risk
- Without proper notice
- If customer offered payment plan

## SB 998 Shutoff Protections

California's [SB 998 Shutoff Protection rules](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/shutoff-protection.html) set statewide minimum standards for water disconnection procedures.

### State Requirements
- Low-income rate assistance
- Crisis assistance
- Percentage of income payment plans

### Eligible Households
- Income-based eligibility
- May link to other assistance programs
- Varies by utility

## Medical Baseline

### What It Is
- Protection for medical needs
- Additional allocation
- Shutoff limitations

### How to Qualify
- Medical certification required
- Life support equipment
- Serious illness

## If You Receive Shutoff Notice

### Steps to Take
1. Contact utility immediately
2. Ask about payment plan
3. Apply for assistance through [CPUC Financial Assistance Programs](https://www.cpuc.ca.gov/consumer-support/financial-assistance-savings-and-discounts)
4. Provide medical documentation if applicable
5. Document all communications

## After Shutoff

### Restoration
- Pay or arrange payment
- Reconnection fees may apply
- Same-day restoration possible

## Resources
- Community action agencies
- 211
- Legal aid organizations
- [California Low-Income Water Rate Assistance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/assistance/) programs

## Take Action

1. **Know your rights** -- Review [SB 998 Shutoff Protection rules](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/shutoff-protection.html) to understand the notice requirements and protections your utility must provide before disconnecting service.
2. **Apply for financial help** -- Visit [CPUC Financial Assistance Programs](https://www.cpuc.ca.gov/consumer-support/financial-assistance-savings-and-discounts) for discounts and payment assistance available to low-income households.
3. **Check rate assistance** -- Explore [California Low-Income Water Rate Assistance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/assistance/) for state programs that reduce water bills for qualifying residents.
4. **Contact your utility immediately** -- If you receive a shutoff notice, call your water utility before the disconnection date to set up a payment plan or apply for assistance.

# Home Water Testing Guide

## When to Test

### Recommended Testing
- When buying property
- After plumbing work
- Taste/odor changes
- Near contamination sources
- If on private well

### What to Test For
- Coliform bacteria
- Nitrate
- Lead (if older home)
- Area-specific contaminants

## Testing Options

### Certified Labs
- [ELAP-certified labs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) required for official results
- Most reliable
- Cost varies ($25-500+ depending on tests)

### Home Test Kits
- Quick screening
- Less accurate
- Not accepted by agencies
- Good for basic checks

### Utility Testing
- May test for specific concerns
- Consumer Confidence Report data
- Contact customer service

## Sample Collection

### Bacteria Testing
- Sterile container required
- Collect first-draw sample
- Keep cool
- Deliver quickly (within 24 hours)

### Lead Testing
- First-draw sample (no flushing)
- Early morning best
- Shows lead from plumbing

## Understanding Results

### Compare To Standards
- MCLs (Maximum Contaminant Levels)
- PHGs (Public Health Goals)
- Action levels (lead/copper)

### If Elevated
- Retest to confirm
- Identify source
- Consider treatment
- Contact health department if serious

## Finding Labs
- [ELAP Online Directory](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) for accredited testing labs
- County environmental health
- Water utility referrals
- Well owners can check the [GAMA Groundwater Information System](https://gamagroundwater.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/gamamap/public/) for existing groundwater data

## Take Action

1. **Find a certified lab** -- Use the [ELAP Online Directory](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) to locate accredited water testing laboratories near you.
2. **Check existing groundwater data** -- Search the [GAMA Groundwater Information System](https://gamagroundwater.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/gamamap/public/) to see if your area already has groundwater quality data on file.
3. **Review drinking water guidance** -- Visit [EPA Home Water Testing](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water) for guidance on what to test for and how to interpret results.
4. **Contact your utility** -- If you are on a public water system, call your utility for the most recent water quality data and ask about testing assistance.

# Point-of-Use Water Treatment

## Types of Treatment

### Activated Carbon Filters
- Removes chlorine, taste, odor
- Some organic chemicals
- Lead (some units)
- Pitcher, faucet-mount, under-sink

### Reverse Osmosis (RO)
- Removes most contaminants
- Under-sink installation
- Wastes some water
- Removes minerals

### Water Softeners
- Removes hardness (calcium, magnesium)
- Ion exchange process
- Adds sodium
- Whole-house systems

### Distillation
- Removes most contaminants
- Counter-top units available
- Slow process
- Removes minerals

### UV Disinfection
- Kills bacteria and viruses
- Doesn't remove chemicals
- Point-of-entry systems

## Choosing Treatment

### Know Your Water Quality
- Test first using an [ELAP-certified lab](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/)
- Identify specific contaminants
- Match treatment to problem

### NSF Certification
- Look for NSF mark -- verify at [NSF International Water Filter Certification](https://www.nsf.org/consumer-resources/articles/standards-water-treatment-systems)
- Specifies contaminants removed
- NSF/ANSI Standards:
  - 42 (aesthetic)
  - 53 (health effects)
  - 58 (RO)

## Maintenance

### Filter Replacement
- Follow manufacturer schedule
- Track filter life
- Set reminders

### System Maintenance
- Annual inspection
- Sanitization
- Check connections

## Cost Considerations
- Initial purchase
- Filter/membrane replacement
- Water waste (RO)
- Professional installation

For additional guidance on treatment technologies, visit [DDW Drinking Water Treatment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/) and [EPA Home Water Treatment](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water).

## Take Action

1. **Test your water first** -- Find an [ELAP-certified lab](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) to identify which contaminants are in your water before selecting a treatment system.
2. **Verify filter certifications** -- Check [NSF International Water Filter Certification](https://www.nsf.org/consumer-resources/articles/standards-water-treatment-systems) to confirm your treatment device is certified for the specific contaminants you need to remove.
3. **Review treatment options** -- Visit [DDW Drinking Water Treatment](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/) for California-specific guidance on home treatment technologies.
4. **Explore EPA resources** -- Check [EPA Home Water Treatment](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water) for consumer guides comparing filter types and treatment effectiveness.

# Water Conservation Tips for Residents

## Indoor Conservation

### Bathroom
- Low-flow showerheads (1.5 gpm)
- WaterSense toilets (1.28 gpf)
- Fix running toilets
- Shorter showers
- Turn off while brushing

### Kitchen
- Full dishwasher loads
- Don't pre-rinse
- Fix dripping faucets
- WaterSense fixtures

### Laundry
- Full loads only
- High-efficiency washer
- Adjust water level

## Outdoor Conservation

### Irrigation
- Water early morning
- Adjust to weather
- Smart controller
- Drip irrigation
- Check for leaks

### Landscaping
- California native plants
- Drought-tolerant species
- Mulch (2-4 inches)
- Turf reduction

### Pool/Spa
- Cover when not in use
- Check for leaks
- Minimize splash-out

## Rebates and Incentives

### Common Programs
- Toilet replacement
- Washing machine
- Turf replacement
- Smart irrigation controllers

### Where to Find
- Water utility website
- [Save Our Water](https://saveourwater.com/) campaign resources
- Local programs

## Water Budgets

### Tiered Rates
- Higher use = higher rate
- Stay within budget
- Monitor bill

## Resources
- [Save Our Water](https://saveourwater.com/) for California conservation tips
- [SWRCB Conservation Programs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/) for statewide conservation rules
- [EPA WaterSense Tips](https://www.epa.gov/watersense/start-saving) for product certifications and savings
- [DWR Water Use Efficiency](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency) for efficiency standards

## Take Action

1. **Find rebates and tips** -- Visit [Save Our Water](https://saveourwater.com/) for California-specific conservation tips, rebate programs, and tools to track your water savings.
2. **Check conservation rules** -- Review [SWRCB Conservation Programs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/conservation/) for current statewide water-use restrictions and permanent conservation rules.
3. **Shop WaterSense products** -- Use [EPA WaterSense Tips](https://www.epa.gov/watersense/start-saving) to find certified low-flow fixtures and appliances that save water without sacrificing performance.
4. **Explore efficiency standards** -- Visit [DWR Water Use Efficiency](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency) to learn about indoor and outdoor water use standards that affect your utility.

# Landscaping for Water Efficiency

## California-Friendly Landscaping

### Principles
- Right plant, right place
- Efficient irrigation
- Soil improvement
- Mulching
- Practical turf areas

## Turf Replacement

### Benefits
- 50-70% water savings
- Lower maintenance
- Rebates available
- Increased property value

### Options
- Native plants
- Drought-tolerant plants
- Permeable hardscape
- Artificial turf (check local rules)

### Rebates
- $1-4 per square foot typical
- Utility programs
- Regional programs
- Requirements vary

## Efficient Irrigation

### Smart Controllers
- Weather-based adjustment
- Soil moisture sensors
- Remote monitoring
- Rebates available

### Drip Irrigation
- Direct to roots
- Less evaporation
- Reduces runoff
- DIY installation possible

### Maintenance
- Check for leaks monthly
- Adjust seasonally
- Repair broken heads promptly

## Model Water Efficient Landscape Ordinance (MWELO)

California's [MWELO](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency/Urban-Water-Use-Efficiency/Model-Water-Efficient-Landscape-Ordinance) applies to:
- New landscapes over 500 sq ft
- Rehabilitated landscapes
- Water budget approach
- Efficient irrigation required

### Requirements
- Maximum applied water allowance
- Landscape documentation
- Certificate of completion

## Resources
- [Save Our Water - Outdoor Tips](https://saveourwater.com/) for turf replacement and native plant guidance
- UC Master Gardener programs
- Local water agency programs
- [EPA WaterSense Outdoors](https://www.epa.gov/watersense/outdoors) for efficient irrigation certifications

## Take Action

1. **Check MWELO requirements** -- Visit [DWR Model Water Efficient Landscape Ordinance](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/Water-Use-And-Efficiency/Urban-Water-Use-Efficiency/Model-Water-Efficient-Landscape-Ordinance) to understand landscape requirements for new or renovated yards.
2. **Find rebates** -- Visit [Save Our Water](https://saveourwater.com/) and your local water utility website for turf replacement rebates and smart irrigation controller incentives.
3. **Shop certified products** -- Check [EPA WaterSense Outdoors](https://www.epa.gov/watersense/outdoors) for certified irrigation controllers and sprinkler heads that meet efficiency standards.
4. **Contact your utility** -- Ask your water agency about landscape audits, free plant lists, and rebate applications available in your service area.

# Understanding Consumer Confidence Reports

## What is a CCR?
- Annual water quality report required for community water systems
- Distributed by July 1 each year
- Covers previous calendar year testing data
- Required under [DDW Consumer Confidence Report Requirements](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html)

## Required Contents

### Source Information
- Where water comes from
- Groundwater or surface water
- Source water assessment results

### Detected Contaminants
- All detected contaminants
- Levels found
- MCL comparison
- Health effects information

### Compliance Status
- Violations and explanations
- Corrective actions taken
- System reliability

## Reading Your CCR

### Understanding the Data
- MCL: Maximum allowed
- MCLG: Health-based goal
- Range: Low to high detected
- Average: Typical level

### Key Contaminants to Note
- Lead and copper results
- Disinfection byproducts
- Bacteria results
- Any MCL violations

## Getting Your CCR

### Delivery Methods
- Mail (paper or postcard)
- Email notification
- Posted online
- Available upon request

### If You Don't Receive
- Contact water utility
- Check utility website
- Request copy

## Using CCR Information

### What to Do If Concerned
- Read health effects information
- Contact utility with questions
- Consider additional testing
- Review treatment options

## Resources
- [EPA Consumer Confidence Reports](https://www.epa.gov/ccr) for national CCR guidance
- [DDW CCR Requirements](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html) for California-specific rules
- [EPA CCR Finder](https://www.epa.gov/ccr/ccr-information-consumers) to search for your system's report
- Local utility website

## Take Action

1. **Find your CCR** -- Use the [EPA CCR Finder](https://www.epa.gov/ccr/ccr-information-consumers) to look up your water system's most recent Consumer Confidence Report online.
2. **Check California requirements** -- Review [DDW Consumer Confidence Report Requirements](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html) to understand what your utility must include in the report.
3. **Learn to interpret results** -- Visit [EPA Consumer Confidence Reports](https://www.epa.gov/ccr) for guidance on reading contaminant tables, understanding MCLs, and identifying violations.
4. **Contact your utility** -- If you have questions about detected contaminants or violations, call the customer service number listed in your CCR.

# Water Quality During Emergencies

## Types of Emergencies

### Natural Disasters
- Earthquakes
- Wildfires
- Floods
- Power outages

### System Emergencies
- Main breaks
- Treatment failures
- Contamination events
- Loss of pressure

## Boil Water Advisories

### When Issued
- Loss of disinfection
- E. coli detection
- Low pressure events
- Main breaks with contamination

### What to Do
- Bring water to rolling boil
- Boil for 1 minute
- Cool before use
- Use bottled water alternative
- Follow the [EPA Emergency Disinfection of Drinking Water](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water/emergency-disinfection-drinking-water) guide for detailed procedures

### What Requires Boiled Water
- Drinking
- Cooking
- Ice making
- Brushing teeth
- Preparing infant formula

### What Doesn't Require Boiling
- Bathing/showering (don't swallow)
- Laundry
- General cleaning

## Do Not Use Advisories

### More Serious Than Boil
- Chemical contamination
- Unknown contamination
- Don't use for any purpose
- Use bottled water only

## Staying Informed

### Alert Systems
- Utility notifications
- Local emergency alerts through [Cal OES Emergency Preparedness](https://www.caloes.ca.gov/)
- News media
- Social media

### All-Clear
- Wait for official notice
- System flushing may be needed
- Follow utility instructions

## Emergency Water Supply

### Recommended Storage
- 1 gallon per person per day
- Minimum 3-day supply
- Store in food-grade containers
- Replace every 6-12 months

For California-specific emergency response, visit the [DDW Emergency Response](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) page. The [CDC Water Safety After Disasters](https://www.cdc.gov/water-emergency/about/index.html) guide provides additional safety information.

## Take Action

1. **Prepare an emergency water supply** -- Store at least 1 gallon per person per day for 3 days, and review [EPA Emergency Disinfection of Drinking Water](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water/emergency-disinfection-drinking-water) for purification methods.
2. **Sign up for alerts** -- Register for local emergency notifications through [Cal OES Emergency Preparedness](https://www.caloes.ca.gov/) and your water utility's alert system.
3. **Bookmark emergency resources** -- Save the [CDC Water Safety After Disasters](https://www.cdc.gov/water-emergency/about/index.html) guide for quick reference during emergencies.
4. **Check DDW guidance** -- Visit the [DDW Emergency Response](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) page for California-specific boil water advisory procedures and utility contact information.

# Environmental Justice and Water

## What is Environmental Justice?
- Fair treatment of all people
- Meaningful involvement in decisions
- Regardless of race, income, origin
- Applied to environmental policies

## Water EJ Issues in California

### Drinking Water
- Disadvantaged communities face contaminated drinking water
- Failing water systems
- Unaffordable water rates

### Pollution Burden
- Industrial facilities near communities
- Contaminated groundwater
- Cumulative impacts tracked by [CalEnviroScreen](https://oehha.ca.gov/calenviroscreen)

## State Response

### SAFER Program
- Focus on disadvantaged communities through the [SAFER Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/)
- Safe and Affordable Drinking Water Fund
- Consolidation assistance
- Interim solutions

### SB 1000 (Planning)
- General plans must address EJ
- For cities with disadvantaged communities
- Identify EJ issues
- Propose solutions

### AB 617 (Air Quality)
- Community air monitoring
- Emission reduction programs
- Community involvement

## CalEnviroScreen

### What It Is
- [CalEnviroScreen mapping tool](https://oehha.ca.gov/calenviroscreen) by OEHHA
- Identifies pollution-burdened communities
- Cumulative impact scores
- Used for program prioritization

### How It's Used
- Funding priorities
- Program eligibility
- Community identification

## Community Resources

### Involvement Opportunities
- Regional Board meetings
- Public comment periods
- Community advisory groups
- Environmental justice organizations

### Support Organizations
- Community Water Center
- Leadership Counsel
- [CalEPA Environmental Justice](https://calepa.ca.gov/envjustice/) programs
- Local EJ organizations
- The [SWRCB Environmental Justice](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/outreach/education/justice.html) page provides resources for community engagement

## Take Action

1. **Map your community's burden** -- Use the [CalEnviroScreen mapping tool](https://oehha.ca.gov/calenviroscreen) to check pollution burden scores and cumulative impacts in your neighborhood.
2. **Explore SAFER funding** -- Visit the [SAFER Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) page to learn how disadvantaged communities can access safe drinking water funding and technical assistance.
3. **Engage with CalEPA** -- Visit [CalEPA Environmental Justice](https://calepa.ca.gov/envjustice/) for information on statewide EJ initiatives, grant opportunities, and community engagement resources.
4. **Attend Water Board meetings** -- Visit the [SWRCB Environmental Justice](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/outreach/education/justice.html) page to find meeting schedules, public comment opportunities, and EJ contacts.
5. **File a complaint** -- If your community faces environmental injustice related to water, file a complaint through the [SWRCB Contact Portal](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/about_us/contact_us/).
